{{other uses2|Thanatopsis}} "'''Thanatopsis'''" is a poem by the American poet [[William Cullen Bryant]]. Meaning 'a consideration of death', the word is derived from the Greek 'thanatos' (death) and 'opsis' (view, sight).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?search=Thanatopsis|title=Thanatopsis - Search Online Etymology Dictionary|website=Etymonline.com|accessdate=30 December 2017}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Brooklyn Museum - William Cullen Bryant - Wyatt Eaton - overall.jpg|thumb|A painting of William Cullen Bryant from 1878]] [[William Cullen Bryant]] was born in 1794 in [[Cummington, Massachusetts]]. Bryant grew up in a Puritan home with his father, Peter Bryant, a prominent doctor. William Cullen Bryant's early education came from his father.{{sfn|Trent|1920|p=258}} In his early life Bryant would spend a great deal of time in the woods surrounding his family's New England home, and read of the extensive personal library his father had.{{sfn|Haralson|2014|p=57}} Bryant's first published poem was "The Embargo; or, Sketches of the Times", a satirical work concerning [[Thomas Jefferson]]'s [[Embargo Act of 1807]]. It was released in a Boston newspaper in 1808. In 1810 Bryant was forced to leave [[Williams College]] for lack of money. Instead of a formal education, he started [[Jurisprudence|studying law]], and began learning an eclectic mix of poetry, such as the works of as [[Isaac Watts]] and [[Henry Kirke White]], and verses like [[William Cowper]]'s "[[The Task (poem)|The Task]]" and [[Edmund Spenser]]'s "[[The Faerie Queene]]".{{sfn|Trent|1920|p=259}}
When and where Bryant wrote "Thanatopsis" is unclear, and Bryant himself could not remember when he wrote the verse.{{sfn|Phelps|1924|p=7}} According to [[Parke Godwin (journalist)|Parke Godwin]], Bryant's friend, Bryant wrote the poem when he was seventeen years old in mid-1811, just after he had left Williams College.{{sfn|Bigelow|1890|p=40}} In ''History of American Literature'', two dates are stated for the authoring of "Thanatopsis", 1811 and 1816.{{sfn|Phelps|1924|p=6}} Bryant's inspiration for "Thanatopsis" came after reading [[William Wordsworth]]'s ''[[Lyrical Ballads]]'',{{sfn|Trent|1917|p=262}} as well as [[Robert Blair (poet)|Robert Blair]]'s "[[The Grave (poem)|The Grave]]", [[Beilby Porteus]]'s "[[Death (poem)|Death]]" and Kirke White's "[[Time (poem)|Time]]".{{sfn|Trent|1917|p=263}} After Bryant had left Cummington to begin his law studies, his father discovered a manuscript in Bryant's desk drawer,{{sfn|Trent|1920|p=261}} that contained "Thanatopsis" and a fragment of a poem, which would be published under the title "The Fragment"<ref>"The Fragment" in North American Review, September 1817[https://www.jstor.org/stable/25121331] </ref>, and later titled "An Inscription upon the Entrance to a Wood".{{sfn|Bigelow|1890|p=40}} He sent the two poems without his son's knowledge to the editors at the ''[[North American Review]]'', where they were published in September 1817.<ref>"Thanatopsis" in North American Review, September 1817[https://www.jstor.org/stable/25121330] </ref> {{sfn|Phelps|1924|p=7}} The editors added an introduction to Thanatopsis in a completely different style. The part written by the author begins with "Yet a few days,". The author republished the poem in 1821 in a collection of works called ''Poems''. He replaced the introductory section, made a few minor changes to the text and added more material after the original end of the poem, which was "and make their bed with thee!". Below is the revised version of 1821 which was retained in all later publications of the poem:
==Thanatopsis== <poem> {{pad|1em}}To him who in the love of Nature holds Communion with her visible forms, she speaks A various language; for his gayer hours She has a voice of gladness, and a smile And eloquence of beauty, and she glides Into his darker musings, with a mild And healing sympathy, that steals away Their sharpness, ere he is aware. When thoughts Of the last bitter hour come like a blight Over thy spirit, and sad images Of the stern agony, and shroud, and pall, And breathless darkness, and the narrow house, Make thee to shudder, and grow sick at heart;— Go forth, under the open sky, and list To Nature’s teachings, while from all around Earth and her waters, and the depths of air— Comes a still voice— {{pad|9em}}Yet a few days, and thee The all-beholding sun shall see no more In all his course; nor yet in the cold ground, Where thy pale form was laid, with many tears, Nor in the embrace of ocean, shall exist Thy image. Earth, that nourished thee, shall claim Thy growth, to be resolved to earth again, And, lost each human trace, surrendering up Thine individual being, shalt thou go To mix for ever with the elements, To be a brother to the insensible rock And to the sluggish clod, which the rude swain Turns with his share, and treads upon. The oak Shall send his roots abroad, and pierce thy mould. {{pad|1em}}Yet not to thine eternal resting-place Shalt thou retire alone, nor couldst thou wish Couch more magnificent. Thou shalt lie down With patriarchs of the infant world—with kings, The powerful of the earth—the wise, the good, Fair forms, and hoary seers of ages past, All in one mighty sepulchre. The hills Rock-ribbed and ancient as the sun,—the vales Stretching in pensive quietness between; The venerable woods—rivers that move In majesty, and the complaining brooks That make the meadows green; and, poured round all, Old Ocean’s gray and melancholy waste,— Are but the solemn decorations all Of the great tomb of man. The golden sun, The planets, all the infinite host of heaven, Are shining on the sad abodes of death, Through the still lapse of ages. All that tread The globe are but a handful to the tribes That slumber in its bosom.—Take the wings Of morning, pierce the Barcan wilderness, Or lose thyself in the continuous woods Where rolls the Oregon, and hears no sound, Save his own dashings—yet the dead are there: And millions in those solitudes, since first The flight of years began, have laid them down In their last sleep—the dead reign there alone. So shalt thou rest, and what if thou withdraw In silence from the living, and no friend Take note of thy departure? All that breathe Will share thy destiny. The gay will laugh When thou art gone, the solemn brood of care Plod on, and each one as before will chase His favorite phantom; yet all these shall leave Their mirth and their employments, and shall come And make their bed with thee. As the long train Of ages glide away, the sons of men, The youth in life’s green spring, and he who goes In the full strength of years, matron and maid, The speechless babe, and the gray-headed man— Shall one by one be gathered to thy side, By those, who in their turn shall follow them. {{pad|1em}}So live, that when thy summons comes to join The innumerable caravan, which moves To that mysterious realm, where each shall take His chamber in the silent halls of death, Thou go not, like the quarry-slave at night, Scourged to his dungeon, but, sustained and soothed By an unfaltering trust, approach thy grave, Like one who wraps the drapery of his couch About him, and lies down to pleasant dreams. </poem>
==Critical reception== Due to the unusual quality of the verse and Bryant's age, [[Richard Henry Dana, Sr.]], then associate editor at the ''North American Review'', initially doubted its authenticity, saying to another editor, "No one, on this side of the Atlantic, is capable of writing such verses."
"Thanatopsis" remains a milestone in American literary history. ''Poems'' was considered by many to be the first major book of American poetry. Nevertheless, over five years, it earned Bryant only $14.92.<ref>Gioia, Dana. "Longfellow in the Aftermath of Modernism". ''The Columbia History of American Poetry'', edited by Jay Parini. Columbia University Press, 1993: 74–75. {{ISBN|0-231-07836-6}}</ref> Poet and literary critic [[Thomas Holley Chivers]], who often accused other writers of stealing poems, said that the only thing Bryant "ever wrote that may be called ''Poetry'' is 'Thanatopsis,' which he stole ''line for line'' from the Spanish."<ref>Parks, Edd Winfield. ''Ante-Bellum Southern Literary Critics''. Athens, GA: University of Georgia Press, 1962: 175.</ref>
==Appearances in popular culture== [[Image:1922 Modern Beacon theatres BostonGlobe 14April.png|thumb|right|Advertisement for 1922 screening of ''Bryant's "Thanatopsis"'' at the [[Modern Theatre (Boston)|Modern]] and [[Beacon Theatre, Boston|Beacon]] cinemas, Boston; part of ''Great American Authors'' film series]] In ''[[The Silence of the Lambs (novel)|The Silence of the Lambs]]'' by [[Thomas Harris]], [[Clarice Starling]] reveals to [[Hannibal Lecter]] one detail of her father's last days in a hospital: an elderly neighbour reading to him the last lines of "Thanatopsis." In [[Sinclair Lewis]]' novel [[Main Street (novel)|Main Street]], the women's study club of Gopher Prairie is the Thanatopsis club.
The experimental band [[Thanatopsis (band)|Thanatopsis]] was named after this poem. The band's first album, ''Thanatopsis'', was also named after this poem. The electronic artist [[Daedelus]] named the last song on the album ''[[Exquisite Corpse (album)|Exquisite Corpse]]'' after the poem.
The Avant Garde film-maker [[Ed Emshwiller]]'s 1962 short film Thanatopsis was inspired by the poem. In the ''[[Space Ghost Coast to Coast]]'' episode "Terminal", a portion of the poem is set to folk music and sung by writer/producer [[Dave Willis]].
In the 1942 film ''[[Grand Central Murder]]'', the private railway car where the showgirl is murdered is named Thanatopsis.
In [[T. Coraghessan Boyle|T.C. Boyle]]'s 1990 novel ''[[East Is East (novel)|East Is East]]'', the writer's colony on the fictitious Georgia sea island of Tupelo (near Darien) is called Thanatopsis House. Each of the artists in the colony have their own private studio cabin to work in during the day. Each studio cabin is named after a famous suicide (example: [[Hart Crane]]).
In [[August Wilson]]'s 2003 play ''[[Gem of the Ocean]]'', Solly offers the final nine lines of the poem ("So live . . . pleasant dreams") as a toast to send off Citizen Barlow to the city of bones. Eli joins Solly in the recitation, offering his own interpretation of the lines: "You die by how you live."
The [[Acacia Fraternity]] adopted the last stanza as their [[:File:Acacia_Fraternity_Code.jpg|code.]]
American progressive rock band [[Kansas (band)|Kansas]]' 2000 studio album ''[[Somewhere to Elsewhere]]'' features a song called ''The Coming Dawn (Thanatopsis)''. The lyrics are a reflection on a life at its end.
The [[Algonquin Round Table]] of the 1920s had its own poker club: the tongue-in-cheek-named Thanatopsis Literary and Inside Straight Club.
Cindy Williams reads from Thanatopsis in Andy Kaufman's ABC TV Special aired in 1979.

Includes a chapter on the poem. {{ISBN|0-8166-4893-X}} * Connie Willis, ''Ado'' (Asimov's Science Fiction, 1988) A short story about political correctness and religious vigilance run amok on campus mentions this poem. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140420061743/http://acacia.org/pythagoras/the-fraternity/the-international-fraternity/ Acacia International Fraternity] * {{cite book|last1=Phelps|first1=William Lyon|authorlink1=William Lyon Phelps|title=Howells, James, Bryant, and Other Essays|date=1924|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers]]|location=New York|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Trent|first1=William Peterfield Trent|authorlink1=William Peterfield Trent|title=A History of American Literature, 1607-1865|date=1920|publisher=[[D. Appleton & Company]]|location=New York|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Trent|first1=William Peterfield Trent|authorlink1=William Peterfield Trent|title=The Cambridge History of American Literature|date=1917|publisher=[[G. P. Putnam's Sons]]|location=New York|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Bigelow|first1=John|title=William Cullen Bryant|date=1890|publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin]]|location=Boston, MA|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|last1=Haralson|first1=Eric L.|authorlink1=Eric L. Pennington-Richards]] | editor = | location = [[Falmouth, Cornwall]], England | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 25 minutes | company = [[Sapphire Films]] | distributor = [[ITC Entertainment]] | channel = [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] | picture_format = [[35 mm film]] [[Aspect ratio (image)|4:3]] Black and white | audio_format = [[Monaural|Mono]] | first_run = | first_aired = 19 September 1956 | last_aired = 12 June 1957 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = | production_website = }} '''''The Buccaneers''''' was a 1956 [[Sapphire Films]] television drama series for [[ITC Entertainment]], broadcast by [[CBS]] in the US and shown on [[Associated TeleVision|ATV]] and regional [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] companies as they came on air during the infancy of [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] in the UK. Starring [[Robert Shaw (British actor)|Robert Shaw]] as Dan Tempest, the series, aimed at children, followed the adventures of Tempest and his crew of former pirates as they made their way across the seven seas in ''Sultana''. This series was one of several swashbuckling adventure series produced during this period by or for [[Lew Grade]]'s ITC. ==Production notes== The series ran for 39 half-hour black-and-white episodes and was produced by [[Hannah Weinstein]] and [[Sidney Cole]] for [[Sapphire Films]] Limited. The episodes were made at [[Nettlefold Studios]] at [[Walton-on-Thames]] using two studios with seven or eight standing sets. A real schooner was based at [[Falmouth, Cornwall]] and a faithful reproduction of part of it in a studio corner.Margaret Cohen feature in TV Times 21 September 1956 page 33 Rupert Evans, stunt artist, former army teacher of physical training taught Robert Shaw fencing. The series was set in the [[Nassau, Bahamas|Port of Nassau]] in [[New Providence]] of about 1722. Sources report that Robert Shaw was unavailable for the first few episodes, but nevertheless shooting went ahead without him. In the majority of episodes, he is listed as "With" rather than "Starring" in the title sequence, for reasons that are open to speculation. The complete series is available on R2 DVD from Network in the UK. There are a number of public-domain DVDs of the series in the North American market, as well as a complete series release. In 1976 Robert Shaw virtually reprised his role on the big screen in ''[[Swashbuckler (film)|Swashbuckler]]''. ==Cast and characters== * [[Robert Shaw (British actor)|Robert Shaw]] as Captain Dan Tempest * [[Peter Hammond (actor)|Peter Hammond]] as Lieutenant Edward Beamish * [[Brian Rawlinson]] as Gaff Guernsey * [[Paul Hansard]] as Taffy * Wilfred Downing as Dickon * [[Edwin Richfield]] as Armando * [[Neil Hallett]] as Boatswain Sam Bassett * [[Willoughby Gray]] as Pop * [[Jane Griffiths (actress)|Jane Griffiths]] as Paula * [[Alec Mango]] as Mr. Van Brugh Various characters were often played by Tony Thawnton, [[Terence Cooper]], [[Rupert Evans]], Roy Purcell and Denis Lacey. ===Historical characters=== * [[Blackbeard]] played by [[George Margo]], [[Terence Cooper]] * [[Woodes Rogers|Governor Woodes Rogers]] played by [[Alec Clunes]] * [[Anne Bonny]] played by [[Hazel Court]] * [[Calico Jack]] played by [[Brian Worth (actor)|Brian Worth]] * [[Bartholomew Roberts|Black Bart]] played by [[Alex Scott (actor)|Alex Scott]] * [[Charles Vane]] ==Episode list== Airdate is for ATV MidlandsBefore 1968 ATV transmitted weekdays in the Midlands and weekends in London. See [[History of ITV]] [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] regions varied date and order. {{Episode table |background=#BFF0FF |overall=|title= |director= |writer= |airdate= |episodes= {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=1 |Title=Blackbeard |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|9|19|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Thomas A. Stockwell |DirectedBy=[[Ralph Smart]] |ShortSummary= Captain and new Governor [[Woodes Rogers]] arrives at (Nassau) New Providence island to clean up the pirates there, where he is authorised by the King to offer them all pardons for their past sins. The men know Rogers from his pirate past that he is an honest man and some accept, but Blackbeard ([[George Margo]]) and some of his crew disagree and make trouble. Rogers stops a duel between Blackbeard and Ben, shooting Blackbeard in the hand, the same hand he uses a minute later to duel using swords, with Rogers. Blackbeard is disarmed but then Rogers is knocked out by Sawney ([[Alfie Bass]]) who is not right in the head. Blackbeard and his men escape to fight another day. Episode also has [[Hugh David]] as Benjy, Andrew Crawford as Captain Ben Hornigold, [[Brian Worth (actor)|Brian Worth]] as Rackam, [[Edwin Richfield]] as Armando, [[Peter Bennett (actor)|Peter Bennett]] as Costellaux, [[Paul Hansard]] as Alfie and [[Patrick Jordan]] as Morgan. The tavern on the island is called "Fountain of Youth." |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=2 |Title=The Raiders |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|9|26|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore |DirectedBy=Ralph Smart |ShortSummary=The date is 1 August 1718, and the island of New Providence is in danger from pirate raiders led by Charles Vane. Governor Rogers must decide on whether to go after Vane, thus leaving the island unprotected, or repairing the damaged fort and waiting for Vane to return and strike again. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=3 |Title=Captain Dan Tempest |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|10|3|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore |DirectedBy=Ralph Smart |ShortSummary=Captain Dan Tempest returns to the island of New Providence. He is several weeks late to accept the pardon and is promptly arrested by Governor Rogers for piracy. He is later approached by Rogers and given a chance to redeem himself by delivering cargo to Charleston. Lt. Beamish accompanies him on the voyage. When they are met on the open sea by Blackbeard, Tempest fights him. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=4 |Title= Dan Tempest's War with Spain |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|10|10|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Zachary Weiss |DirectedBy=[[Leslie Arliss]] |ShortSummary=Governor Rogers has left for Jamaica before this episode starts, with Hornigold. The Spanish land what appears to be a friendly force on the island, then take over and tell Beamish that now Spain is at war with England. Tempest has decided to go back to his pirating ways, but instead saves the Fort with his three shipmates. Episode also has [[Robert Rietti]] as Capt. Philip Catalan. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=5 |Title=The Wasp |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|10|17|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Peter C. Hodgkins |DirectedBy=[[Terry Bishop]] |ShortSummary= Dickon (Wilfred Downing) is a wild young boy nicknamed "The Wasp". It is 13 September 1718, and Tempest is given a commission to be a privateer. Dickon is captured by Tempest and becomes his cabin boy, and unknowingly leads Tempest into Blackbeard's trap on his brig "Queen Anne's Revenge" (Blackbeard is now played by [[Terence Cooper]] who at other times goes back to playing Costellaux). |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=6 |Title=Whale Gold |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|10|24|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Zachary Weiss |DirectedBy=Leslie Arliss |ShortSummary=[[Ambergris]], a waxy substance secreted by sperm whales, is needed to make perfumes and is worth five times as much as gold. Greed strikes the men and there are betrayals and death. Terence Cooper again plays a villain, Grimes, and old hand [[Noel Purcell (actor)|Noel Purcell]] played Pat with Tony Thawnton playing Sykes. Also stars [[Eynon Evans]] as Deacon and [[Earl Cameron (actor)|Earl Cameron]] as Sam. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=7 |Title=The Slave Ship |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|10|31|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Jack Cousins |DirectedBy=Terry Bishop |ShortSummary=Slaves take over a ship. Tempest captures them and, using money taken from the slaver, frees them to work on New Providence. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=8 |Title= Gunpowder Plot |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|11|7|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore |DirectedBy=Leslie Arliss |ShortSummary= Blackbeard steals the garrison's gunpowder supply and Tempest has to find a new supplier against the wishes of the naval authorities. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=9 |Title=The Ladies |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|11|14|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Roger McDougall |DirectedBy=[[C.M. Pennington-Richards|Pennington Richards]] |ShortSummary=Tempest hears of Blackbeard plan to board the vessel "Caroline" under a flag of truce to steal its cargo- Women! |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=10 |Title=The Surgeon of Sangre Rojo |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|11|21|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Thomas A. Stockwell |DirectedBy=Pennington Richards |ShortSummary= There is an epidemic on New Providence, and the only way to cure it is to kidnap a Spanish doctor while running a gauntlet of Spanish guns. [[Alec Mango]] again plays the villain whose rotting furs are full of typhus-carrying fleas. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=11 |Title=Before the Mast |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|11|28|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Roger McDougall |DirectedBy=Ralph Smart |ShortSummary=Sailors on New Providence are press-ganged into the service of Spanish pirates under El Supremo ([[Ferdy Mayne]]), who is attacking supply ships. Tempest and Dickon go undercover to stop them, intercepting the "Felicity", which is bringing supplies to their island. Also stars Roger Snowdon as Rodrigues and Salvin Stewart as One-Eye. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=12 |Title= Dan Tempest and the Amazons |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|12|5|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Zachary Weiss |DirectedBy=Pennington Richards |ShortSummary=French pirates attempt to sell seven women to New Providence. They take over Tempest's ship then beat him, but help is at hand from the women. Starring [[Joan Sims]] as chief of the "wimmin". |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=13 |Title=The Articles of War |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|12|12|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Peggy Phillips and Alan Moreland |DirectedBy=Leslie Arliss |ShortSummary=There is a Spanish presence in the area is stopping food reaching the island, so they are living on fish ... unlike the 9 Spanish prisoners who are eating meat under the articles of war. Armando, Gaff and Taffy decide to do something about it. There is success in that the Spanish ship is blown up and the promised food ship arrives, and failure in that now they now have 49 prisoners who are all eating better than they are. Stars [[Eric Pohlmann]] as Capt. Hernandez. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=14 |Title=The Hand of the Hawk |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|12|19|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Peter C. Hodgking |DirectedBy=[[Robert Day (director)|Robert Day]] |ShortSummary=Chantey Jack ([[Sid James]]) is a wandering minstrel (Sid James sings in this episode) who knew Dickon's father, Johnny Spencer. Jack is killed, but not before he has talked of "The Hawk", given Dickon a map and the others a song which tells where treasure is buried. [[Anthony Dawson]] plays Captain Flask. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=15 |Title=Marooned |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1956|12|26|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Peter C. Hodgking |DirectedBy=Leslie Arliss |ShortSummary= Captain Clip West ([[Bill Owen (actor)|Bill Owen]]), a pirate who even gives other pirates a bad name, is captured by Tempest after stealing from New Providence. West persuades the gullible Phineas Bunch ([[Willoughby Goddard]]) to release him. He and his men take over the ship and maroon Tempest and his men, but it is not long before the tables are turned again. Also stars Michael Rathborne as Look-out. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=16 |Title= Gentleman Jack and the Lady |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|1|2|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Zachary Weiss |DirectedBy=Leslie Arliss |ShortSummary=Dan Tempest cheats French privateer Gentleman Jack (actually a woman, Anne Bonny, played by [[Hazel Court]]) out of a prize ship by a clever ruse. Bonny tries threats and tricks, then woman's wiles to get it back. She gets it in the end, minus its valuable cargo. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=17 |Title=Mr Beamish and the Hangman's Noose |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|1|9|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore |DirectedBy=Pennington Richards |ShortSummary= Van Brugh ([[Alec Mango]]) has put some bad words in about Acting Governor Beamish to England. Mainwaring (Lewis Gedge) is the new Governor and Admiral Bingham ([[Stringer Davis]]) has to decide whether Beamish is guilty of running an island full of pirates and should therefore be hanged. Mainwaring is strong on discipline and wants to change everything on the island, but Tempest believes that greed is his weakness and has a plan involving buried treasure that he believes will beat Mainwaring. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=18 |Title=Dead Man's Rock |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|1|16|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Peter C. Hodgkins |DirectedBy=Robert Day |ShortSummary=The "Sultana" is beached so her hull can be scraped. The Spaniards attack and Beamish is kidnapped by the evil Rodriguez ([[Richard Pasco]]) along with Dickon to try to make Beamish reveal the date of a secret convoy. Tempest, with his ship being overhauled, can offer no resistance. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=19 |Title=Blood Will Tell |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|1|23|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Zachary Weiss |DirectedBy=Robert Day |ShortSummary=A trader's estate, Gresham Island, is at stake. The heir is missing and Piggott (Dawson France), whom Dickon recognises as a thief he once knew, is after it and Dickon knows he will be happy to trade with the enemy, Spain. The only way Tempest and Dickon can stop this is for Dickon to pretend to be an heir too. Lawyer Pym ([[Willoughby Goddard]]) must decide who is the real heir. Also stars John Dearth as Bellows. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=20 |Title=Dangerous Cargo |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|1|30|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Zachary Weiss |DirectedBy=Leslie Arliss |ShortSummary= Captain Steele ([[Ivan Craig]]) delivers Lady Hilary Winrod ([[Sarah Lawson (actress)|Sarah Lawson]]) to Dan Tempest so he can take her to Lord Winrod ([[Derek Nimmo]]) in Barbados, supposedly for a honeymoon. Captain Mendoza ([[Roger Delgado]]), a Spanish Captain, tries to kidnap her, and it is up to Tempest to get her to safety after he finds out the real purpose of her mission. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=21 |Title=The Return of Calico Jack |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|2|6|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Zachary Weiss and Basil Dawson |DirectedBy=Pennington Richards |ShortSummary=The villainous Calico Jack ([[Brian Worth (actor)|Brian Worth]]) turns up on New Providence. Tempest is away taking a valuable cargo to the Carolinas. After causing some trouble, Calico Jack learns of the cargo, and so plans to ambush Tempest using the "Sultana", hatching a plan with the equally evil Van Brugh. It's up to Beamish and Tempest's shipmates who have been left behind to stop him. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=22 |Title=Ghost Ship |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|2|13|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Peter C. Hodgking |DirectedBy=Robert Day |ShortSummary= Dickon accidentally kills an albatross, a sign of bad luck. This continues when they find a derelict ship, which is taken in tow with Gaff and Dickon aboard, but the ship seems to be haunted by its original owner; the blood thirsty pirate Captain Van Der Meer whom Taffy saw executed 15 years ago. Then Dickon disappears. Stars [[Colin Douglas (actor)|Colin Douglas]] as De Groot and [[Alfred Burke]] his mate. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=23 |Title=Conquistador |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|2|20|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore and Basil Dawson |DirectedBy=Robert Day |ShortSummary=The "Sultana" sports a jolly roger and her crew attacks ships and now threatens New Providence unless they pay them £10,000. The citizens call for Tempest and his crew to be shot, not knowing that they are prisoners on the "Sultana", which is now in the hands of Don Fernando Estaban ([[Roger Delgado]]) and his men who are pretending to be Tempest and her crew. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=24 |Title=Mother Doughty's Crew |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|2|27|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Zachary Weiss |DirectedBy=Pennington Richards |ShortSummary=Gaff Guernsey is ready to get married, but finds out too late that his bride-to-be Betsy's (Anna Walmsley) mother, Mother Doughty (Ena Burrill), is with her five sons leading undercover pirate raids, which Tempest is trying to stop. Gaff is torn between his loyalty to Betsy and her mother and Tempest and his friends. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=25 |Title=Conquest of New Providence |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|3|6|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore |DirectedBy=[[Leslie Arliss]] and Robert Day |ShortSummary=While Tempest and his crew have been away, Don Estaban ([[Roger Delgado]]) has taken over New Providence. Tempest and Beamish's plans are hampered by traitors who betray them to the Spanish. Tempest is helped by Maria (Gillian Owen), who is Armando's wife. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=26 |Title=Hurricane |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|3|13|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore and Peggy Phillips |DirectedBy=Leslie Arliss |ShortSummary= A hurricane has caused great damage on New Providence. It has also blown a Spanish treasure ship onto rocks nearby, money for the war against England. It is up to Tempest and his men to rescue the gold with the help of local Indians/natives, persuaded by Armando who is one of them. Stars [[Ewen Solon]] as Spanish Admiral and Derek Sydney as Spanish Lieutenant. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=27 |Title=Cutlass Wedding |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|3|20|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Thomas A. Stockwel |DirectedBy=Robert Day |ShortSummary=The women from Episode 12 are back. They are fed up because while the men like their company, no one wants to marry them, and unless someone does they are leaving. Taff has a narrow escape, then it's down to Sam Bassett, Beamish's number two man. The women, led by Abigail ([[Joan Sims]]), find out he is being pushed into marriage and decide to leave the island, only to wind up in the hands of slave traders led by La Forte ([[Paul Eddington]]). |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=28 |Title=The Aztec Treasure |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|3|27|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore |DirectedBy=Pennington Richards |ShortSummary=A man named Martin (Thomas G. Duggan) asks Tempest to help him get hold of Aztec treasure (gold), which the Spanish are also after. Five start into the jungle but only two make it to the gold where the Aztecs capture Tempest and Martin. Also stars [[Frederick Treves (actor)|Frederick Treves]] as Quetzl. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=29 |Title=Prize of Andalusia |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|4|3|df=y}} |WrittenBy= Basil Dawson and Zachary Weiss |DirectedBy=[[Peter Maxwell]] |ShortSummary= £20,000 worth of gold has been stolen from a merchant ship bound for the British navy and is in the hands of a greedy and wicked old Spanish Marquesa ([[Jean Cadell]]), who is going to cheat King Phillip out of it and keep it. Tempest and his men decide to get it back for England, but have to contend with the Marquesa's many tricks and with her men, Sebastian ([[Conrad Phillips]]) and Gomez ([[Bruno Barnabe]]). |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=30 |Title=Dan Tempest Holds an Auction |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|4|10|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Alan Moreland |DirectedBy=Peter Maxwell |ShortSummary= Dan Tempest takes a cargo to Charleston to sell. The "Company" (unnamed) are in charge there, make the rules and pay a third or less of what a cargo is worth, using strong-arm tactics on any who oppose them. Tempest decides to break their monopoly so all traders can get a fair price. Robert Perceval as Sir Charles Johnson, [[Ballard Berkeley]] as Rafton, [[Jane Griffiths (actress)|Jane Griffiths]] as Paula Meadows, [[John Harvey (actor)|John Harvey]] as Lawyer Knox and [[Max Faulkner (actor)|Max Faulkner]] as Guard. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=31 |Title=The Spy Aboard |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|4|17|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Neil R. Collins |DirectedBy=Robert Day |ShortSummary=Dan Tempest decides to bury his treasure for safekeeping, but he and his men are surprised by Pegleg, alias the bullet-proof Captain Finn ([[Richard Johnson (actor)|Richard Johnson]]) and his crew, who steal the treasure. Tempest realises that there must be a spy on the "Sultana" and sets about planting a spy in Pegleg's crew. Stars [[Wilfrid Brambell]] as Old Man, also [[John Salew]] as Cookie, [[Danny Green (actor)|Danny Green]] as Noah and [[Jack Hedley]] as Raikes. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=32 |Title=Flip and Jenny |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|4|24|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Neil R. Collins |DirectedBy=Peter Maxwell |ShortSummary= Two children, Flip (Peter Soule) and Jenny ([[Jane Asher]]), are stowaways. Their father Purdy, ([[Colin Douglas (actor)|Colin Douglas]]), an indentured servant to Lord Hinch ([[Robert Hardy]]), has gone to jail for demanding that his children be educated and for refusing to work until they are. To solve their problems, Tempest lets himself and his men be captured. Also stars Seymour Green as Constable Herridge. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=33 |Title=Indian Fighters |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|5|1|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Neil R. Collins |DirectedBy=Peter Maxwell |ShortSummary=The "Sultana" is taking "Understandable Perkins" (Ronan O'Casey) back to Charleston. Perkins and his fellow Indian fighters have gotten rid of the Indians from around Charleston, making the land worth four times as much, and they refuse to pay the new rent. First, Tempest and his men go to jail and then Perkins, then they hatch a plan to bring the Indians back so the Indian fighters are needed again. Also stars [[Edmund Warwick]] as Magistrate Mortimer and [[Max Faulkner (actor)|Max Faulkner]] as Servant. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=34 |Title=Mistress Higgin's Treasure |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|5|8|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Thomas A. Stockwel |DirectedBy=Pennington Richards |ShortSummary=The "Sultana" is delivering tax-free farm implements to Virginia because they are too expensive to buy locally, but they find the crops have already been harvested. However, they have been stolen so the farmers have lost everything, until schoolmistress Higgins ([[Adrienne Corri]]) helps them find where the crops went. [[Howard Pays]] as Pennington, boys - Barry Fennell and Claude Kingston, girl - [[Jane Asher]]. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=35 |Title=To the Rescue |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|5|15|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Phillis Miller |DirectedBy=Peter Maxwell |ShortSummary=Major Percy ([[Ewen Solon]]) is offering a miserly price for a tobacco crop on behalf of the Crown. Louis Brion (Andre Charisse) needs a good price, and Tempest's girlfriend Paula ([[Jane Griffiths (actress)|Jane Griffiths]]) persuades him to take the cargo where he can get a good price for it, but in doing so they are discovered and the cargo impounded. Percy now has Captain Barker ([[Michael Golden (actor)|Michael Golden]]) take the crop to London for sale for him. If Tempest tries to stop him, he will be accused of piracy, but Tempest has a plan. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=36 |Title=The Decoy |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|5|22|df=y}} |WrittenBy= Albert G. Ruben |DirectedBy=Pennington Richards |ShortSummary= The "Sultana" comes on a woman, Rebecca ([[Virginia Maskell]]), in a rowing boat. Tempest suspects she is a decoy to lure them into the hands of the terrible Turk ([[Marne Maitland]]), but she insists that the Turk is holding her husband, George Bradbury ([[Derek Waring]]), captive. Tempest decides to turn the tables and use the woman as a decoy against the Turk. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=37 |Title=Instrument of War |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|5|29|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Peter Rossano |DirectedBy=Bernard Knowles |ShortSummary=Tempest and his crew with the help of Dougal ([[John Harvey (actor)|John Harvey]]) are trying to get David MacGregor (Charles Houston) off of Prisoner's Island (where they have been transported to) to Port Royal where he can plead the Scot's case. Marsh ([[Alfred Burke]]) is in charge and intends on hanging David. The "Instruments of War" are bagpipes used to call other Scots to battle. Also stars [[Andrew Keir]] as David's father (The Laird), Gay Cameron as Sheila, his girlfriend and Dennis Edwards as Second Guard. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=38 |Title=Pirate Honour |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|6|5|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Marion Myers |DirectedBy=Peter Maxwell |ShortSummary=Captain Drewitt was murdered and now his wife (Ilona Ference) and son, Edwin ([[Michael Caridia]]) must manage as best as they can. But Major Langley ([[Brian Oulton]]) is after the Captain's treasure and sets the evil Black Bart ([[Alex Scott (actor)|Alex Scott]]) on Tempest when he tries to help them. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=39 |Title=Printer's Devil |OriginalAirDate={{Start date|1957|6|12|df=y}} |WrittenBy=Terence Moore |DirectedBy=Bernard Knowles |ShortSummary=Under the guise of doing necessary work, Josiah Parkerhouse ([[Miles Malleson]]) has been printing a newssheet telling the truth about Sir Joplin James ([[Noel Coleman]]) and his cronies when Tempest saves him from being arrested. Tempest lets Parkerhouse continue his printing of the truth aboard the "Sultana", despite a Customs & Excise officer being aboard and then, with the help of a woman who sells bread and such, distributes it to the people on the island, and it isn't long before Sir James is kicked out of his office. Also starred Maxwell Shaw as Sharp, Jean Bloor as Mrs Miles (baker), Walter Horsburgh as Magistrate and Dennis Edwards as an Officer. |LineColor=BFF0FF }} }} ==Music== [[File:Robert Shaw - Radio TV Mirror, July 1957.jpg|thumb|Robert Shaw as Captain Dan Tempest]] The show's ending theme contained the chorus:
Let's go a-roving, a-roving across the ocean
Oh, let's go a-roving and join the buccaneers!
We'll find adventure, adventure across the ocean
Oh, we'll find adventure and join the buccaneers!
[[Sea shanty|Sea shanties]] and traditional songs were incorporated into the show. Early episodes begin with sailors singing "Blow, Ye Winds, in the Morning," an anachronistic American [[whaling]] song. The second episode, "The Raiders," is the only episode to use "[[The Maid of Amsterdam]]" as its ending theme. Other songs performed in the show include: * "[[Drunken Sailor]]" (in "Printer's Devil") * "Haul Away, Joe" (in various episodes including "Dan Tempest's War with Spain") * "Johnny Come Down to Hilo" (in "Mother Doughty's Crew") * "[[Spanish Ladies]]" (in "The Ladies") * "Shake Her, Johnny, Shake Her" (in "Hurricane" and "Flip and Jenny") * "Venezuela" by [[John Jacob Niles]] (in "Mother Doughty's Crew") ==DVD releases== [[Mill Creek Entertainment]] released the complete series in Region 1 on 15 August 2006.https://www.amazon.com/Buccaneers-Complete-Robert-Shaw/dp/B000H5U6AC This release has been discontinued and is now out of print. [[Network DVD]] released the complete series in region 2 on 1 June 2007Network promo [http://www.networkdvd.net/product_info.php?cPath=28&products_id=16] retrieved Dec 2011 On 19 August 2008, [[Timeless Media Group]] released a 3-disc best-of set that features 30 episodes of the series.https://www.amazon.com/Buccaneers-Robert-Shaw/dp/B0019BI0WE ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/1131436/ Screen Online] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051204114432/http://www.angelfire.com/retro/cta/UK/Buccaneers.htm CTA information] * {{IMDb title|id=0048850|title=The Buccaneers}} *{{IMDb name|id=0263193|name= Rupert Evans}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070712230314/http://islands.thebahamian.com/map_nasraw.jpg] Modern map of New Providence. {{Pirates}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Buccaneers, The}} [[Category:1956 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:1957 British television programme endings]] [[Category:British drama television series]] [[Category:Television series by ITC Entertainment]] [[Category:ITV television dramas]] [[Category:Piracy in fiction]] [[Category:British adventure television series]] [[Category:1950s British drama television series]] [[Category:Television series set in the 18th century]] [[Category:Black-and-white British television programmes]] [[Category:English-language television programs]]

{{Infobox Magazine | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = Mark Rogers | editor_title = Senior Editor | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | frequency = Biweekly | circulation = | category = [[Travel industry]] | company = Questex, LLC | publisher = John McMahon | founded = 1930 | country = United States | based = New York City | language = English | website = {{official website|http://www.travelagentcentral.com}} | issn = }} '''''Travel Agent''''' is a biweekly [[trade magazine]], published by Questex, LLC and targeted at [[travel agency]] professionals, featuring [[travel industry]] news.<ref>{{cite web|title=Travel Agent Magazine|url=http://www.travelmediakit.com/travel-agents/print/travelagentmagazine/|work=Questex Travel Group|accessdate=22 March 2017}}</ref><ref name=pub>{{cite web|title=Travel Agent Magazine|url=http://www.publicitas.com/singapore/media-solutions/factsheet/mediadata/travel-agent-magazine/?PARAM1=QSETD1#.VlXqsd_hD6Y|work=Publicitas|accessdate=25 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=The Industry’s Most Read Trade Publication|url=http://www.travelmediakit.com/travel-agents/print/travelagentmagazine/|accessdate=4 August 2015|work=Questex Travel Group}}</ref> It is based in New York City.<ref name=pub/><ref>{{cite book|author=Robert Brewer|title=2009 Writer's Market|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9dIu0FiIDT0C&pg=PT2802|accessdate=25 November 2015|date=1 June 2008|publisher=F+W Media, Inc|isbn=1-58297-677-5|page=2802}}</ref>
==History and profile== The magazine was established in 1930.<ref name="prn">{{cite news|title=Seventeen Virtuoso(R) Members Named Among Travel Agent Magazine's 'Top 25 Agents'|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/seventeen-virtuosor-members-named-among-travel-agent-magazines-top-25-agents-59994247.html|accessdate=22 March 2017|work=PR Newswire|date=21 September 2009}}</ref><ref name="wrn">{{cite news|title=Advanstar Acquires Travel Agent Magazine|url=http://www.writenews.com/advanstar-acquires-travel-agent-magazine-81819985|accessdate=22 March 2017|work=The Write News|date=18 August 1998}}</ref> In 1998 ''Travel Agent'' was sold by Universal Media, Inc. to Advanstar Communications Inc.<ref name="wrn"/> It was formerly published on a weekly basis.<ref name="wrn"/>
''Travel Agent'' targets travel agents, agency owners/managers, and other travel industry staff.<ref name="prn"/> The magazine is also supplemented with an online edition. Questex Media also operates ''Travel Agent University'', an on-line travel education site.<ref name="ta">{{cite web|url=http://www.travelagentcentral.com/about-us|title=About Us|work=Travel Agent|accessdate=28 December 2008}}</ref> Sister publications include: ''Luxury Travel Advisor'', ''Home Based Travel Agent'', ''Official Travel Industry Directory'', ''[[Hotel & Motel Management]]'', ''Premier Hotels & Resorts'' and ''Premier Spas & Romance''.<ref name="ta"/>
Travel Agent is the recipient of ''[[Folio (magazine)|Folio]]'' magazine's editorial excellence award in the travel trade category.<ref>{{cite news|title=Travel Agent Magazine Sold to Advanstar Communications|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Travel+Agent+Magazine+Sold+to+Advanstar+Communications.-a021190149|accessdate=22 March 2017|work=Business Wire|date=24 August 1998}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{About|Fijian culture|the Vanuatu-based indigenous movement|Turaga nation}} In [[Fijian language|Fijian]], '''Turaga''' is the word for a [[man]].
The ''Turaga-ni-Koro'' is a title for the head of a village (''Koro''), who is usually elected or appointed by the villagers.<ref>{{Cite web |last = Naiker |first = Utkatu |authorlink = |title = Local Government in Asia and the Pacific: A Comparative Study |work = Country paper: Fiji |publisher = UNESCAP |url = http://www.unescap.org/huset/lgstudy/country/fiji/fiji.html |doi = |accessdate = 2007-02-23 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131103090813/http://www.unescap.org/huset/lgstudy/country/fiji/fiji.html |archivedate = 2013-11-03 |df = }} </ref> As kind of city administrator or mayor, he plays a key role in the modern [[Politics of Fiji|Fijian government]] structure and is paid a small government allowance.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lucas |first=Verona |authorlink= |author2=Nauque, Setefano |author3=Chandra, Sachin |title=Assessing Community Perspectives on Governance in Fiji |work=RETA 6065 |publisher=FSPI |date=2003 |url=http://www.fspi.org.fj/program/governance/pdfs/5%20RETA%206065%20(Fiji).pdf |format=pdf |doi= |accessdate=2007-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060529003244/http://www.fspi.org.fj/program/governance/pdfs/5%20RETA%206065%20%28Fiji%29.pdf |archivedate=May 29, 2006 |df= }} </ref>
Similarly, the chief of a ''Mataqali'' (clan) is known as the ''Turaga-ni-mataqali''. The exact historical status of the Turaga played an important role in conflicts regarding [[common land]]ownership.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Boydell | first = Spike | authorlink = |author2=Shah, Krishn | title = An inquiry into the nature of land ownership in Fiji | work = | publisher = The International Association for the Study of Common Property | date = 2003 | url = http://dlc.dlib.indiana.edu/archive/00001208/00/Boydell_&_Shah_inquiry_into_land.pdf | format = pdf | doi = | accessdate = 2007-02-23 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}
==Other uses== Turaga was used by The LEGO Group for their toy line Bionicle.
</ref>

'''Women in geology''' concerns the history and contributions of [[Woman|women]] to the field of [[geology]]. There has been a long history of women in the field, but they have tended to be under-represented. In the era before the eighteenth century, science and geological science had not been as formalized as they would become later. Hence early geologists tended to be informal observers and collectors, whether they were male or female. Notable examples of this period include [[Hildegard of Bingen]] who wrote works concerning stones and [[Barbara Uthmann]] who supervised her husband's mining operations after his death. Mrs. Uthmann was also a relative of [[Georg Agricola]]. In addition to these names varied aristocratic women had scientific collections of rocks or minerals.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kölbl-Ebert|first1=M.|title=On the origin of women geologists by means of social selection: German and British comparison|journal=Episodes|date=September 2001|volume=24|issue=3|pages=182–193|url=http://www.episodes.org/index.php/epi/article/view/62654/48865|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref>
In the nineteenth century a new professional class of geologists emerged that included women. In this period the British tended to have far more women of significance to geology.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Creese|first1=Mary R. S.|last2=Creese|first2=Thomas M.|title=British women who contributed to research in the geological sciences in the nineteenth century|journal=The British Journal for the History of Science|date=5 January 2009|volume=27|issue=01|page=23|doi=10.1017/S0007087400031654}}</ref>
In 1977 the [[Association for Women Geoscientists]] was formed to support women in this field as they remained under-represented. There have been advances since then although retention remains a problem.
== Timeline of women in geology == * 1642: [[Martine Bertereau]], the first recorded woman [[mineralogist]], was imprisoned in France on suspicion of witchcraft.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=S_NJ7AubQIcC&pg=PA7&lpg=PA7&dq=Martine+Bertereau+mineralogist&source=bl&ots=gXTogKi3DD&sig=589JD1mH_A45XHU9o3wik0WfkKg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjUrb-7io7dAhVBuVkKHSxEDZoQ6AEwD3oECAAQAQ#v=onepage&q=Martine%20Bertereau%20mineralogist&f=false|title=Women in Chemistry: Their Changing Roles from Alchemical Times to the Mid-twentieth Century|last=Rayner-Canham|first=Marelene F.|last2=Rayner-Canham|first2=Marelene|last3=Rayner-Canham|first3=Geoffrey|date=2001|publisher=Chemical Heritage Foundation|year=|isbn=9780941901277|location=|pages=7|language=en}}</ref> * 1865: [[Elizabeth Carne]] was elected the first female Fellow of the [[Royal Geological Society of Cornwall]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hardie-Budden|first=Melissa|date=|title=Elizabeth Catherine Thomas Carne: A 19th century Hypatia|url=http://www.academia.edu/6703449/Elizabeth_Catherine_Thomas_Carne_A_19th_century_Hypatia|journal=|language=en|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> * 1889: [[Mary Emilie Holmes]] became the first female Fellow of the [[Geological Society of America]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Edwin Butt Eckel|title=The Geological Society of America: Life History of a Learned Society|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BTpRE_p1xnwC&pg=PR9|year=1982|publisher=Geological Society of America|isbn=978-0-8137-1155-3|page=36}}</ref> * 1893: [[Florence Bascom]] became the second woman to earn her Ph.D in geology in the United States, and the first woman to receive a Ph.D from [[Johns Hopkins University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dla.library.upenn.edu/dla/pacscl/ead.html?id=PACSCL_BMC_USPBmBMC198001 |title=Florence Bascom papers, 1883-1938 |publisher=Dla.library.upenn.edu |date= |accessdate=2018-07-28}}</ref><ref name="ucalgary1945">{{cite web|last1=Clary|first1=R.M.|title=Great expectations: Florence Bascom (1842–1945) and the education of early US women geologists|url=http://sp.lyellcollection.org.ezproxy.lib.ucalgary.ca/content/281/1/123|website=Geological society of London Publications|publisher=Special Publications|accessdate=10 October 2017|ref=281, 123-135}}</ref> Geologists consider her to be the "first woman geologist in this country [America]."<ref name="schneidermann1997">{{cite web|url=http://www.gsahist.org/gsat/gt98feb8_9.pdf|title=A Life of Firsts: Florence Bascom|last=Schneidermann|first=Jill|date=July 1997|website=GSA Today|publisher=[[Geological Society of America]]|access-date=}}</ref> * 1896: [[Florence Bascom]] became the first woman to work for the [[United States Geological Survey]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nps.gov/people/the-stone-lady-florence-bascom.htm |title=The Stone Lady, Florence Bascom (U.S. National Park Service) |publisher=Nps.gov |date=1945-06-18 |accessdate=2018-07-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geosociety.org/gsatoday/archive/8/7/pdf/i1052-5173-8-7-8.pdf|title=A Life of Firsts: Florence Bascom|last=Schneidermann|first=Jill|date=July 1997|website=GSA Today|publisher=[[Geological Society of America]]|access-date=}}</ref> * 1901: [[Florence Bascom]] became the first female geologist to present a paper before the Geological Survey of Washington.<ref name="wordpress1">{{cite web|author=irishawg |url=https://irishawg.wordpress.com/2017/12/01/women-in-geoscience-part-2/ |title=Women in Geoscience Series – Irish Association for Women in Geosciences |publisher=Irishawg.wordpress.com |date=2016-08-20 |accessdate=2018-07-28}}</ref> * 1909: [[Alice Wilson]] became the first female geologist hired by the [[Geological Survey of Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.science.ca/scientists/scientistprofile.php?pID=274 |title=Alice Wilson |publisher=science.ca |date= |accessdate=2018-08-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.science.gc.ca/eic/site/063.nsf/eng/97252.html |title=66. Ottawa Geology (1946) |publisher=Science.gc.ca |date=2017-03-03 |accessdate=2018-08-08}}</ref> She is widely credited as being the first Canadian woman geologist.<ref name="Wilson">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/alice-evelyn-wilson/|title=Alice Wilson|last=James-Abra|first=Erin|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en}}</ref> * 1924: [[Florence Bascom]] became the first woman elected to the Council of the [[Geological Society of America]].<ref name="wordpress1"/> * 1936: [[Inge Lehmann]] discovered that the Earth has a solid inner core distinct from its molten [[outer core]].<ref>{{cite book|editor=Edmond A. Mathez |title=EARTH: INSIDE AND OUT |date=2000 |publisher=American Museum of Natural History |url=http://www.amnh.org/education/resources/rfl/web/essaybooks/earth/p_lehmann.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430105106/http://www.amnh.org/education/resources/rfl/web/essaybooks/earth/p_lehmann.html |archivedate=2008-04-30 |df= }}</ref> * 1938: [[Alice Wilson]] became the first woman appointed as Fellow to the [[Royal Society of Canada]].<ref name="Wilson"/> * 1942: American geologist [[Marguerite Williams]] became the first African-American woman to receive a PhD in geology in the United States.
